name: London - Negore, the Coward
body:
He had followed the trail of his fleeing people for eleven
days, and his pursuit had been in itself a flight; for behind him
he knew full well were the dreaded Russians, toiling through the
swampy lowlands and over the steep divides, bent on no less than
the extermination of all his people.Â  He was travelling
light.Â  A rabbit-skin sleeping-robe, a muzzle-loading rifle,
and a few pounds of sun-dried salmon constituted his
outfit.Â  He would have marvelled that a whole
peopleâwomen and children and agedâcould travel so
swiftly, had he not known the terror that drove them on.
It was in the old days of the Russian occupancy of Alaska,
when the nineteenth century had run but half its course, that
Negore fled after his fleeing tribe and came upon it this summer
night by the head waters of the Pee-lat.Â  Though near the
midnight hour, it was bright day as he passed through the weary
camp.Â  Many saw him, all knew him, but few and cold were the
greetings he received.
âNegore, the Coward,â he heard Illiha, a young
woman, laugh, and Sun-ne, his sisterâs daughter, laughed
with her.
Black anger ate at his heart; but he gave no sign, threading
his way among the camp-fires until he came to one where sat an
old man.Â  A young woman was kneading with skilful fingers
the tired muscles of his legs.Â  He raised a sightless face
and listened intently as Negoreâs foot crackled a dead
twig.
âWho comes?â he queried in a thin, tremulous
voice.
âNegore,â said the young woman, scarcely looking
up from her task.
Negoreâs face was expressionless.Â  For many minutes
he stood and waited.Â  The old manâs head had sunk back
upon his chest.Â  The young woman pressed and prodded the
wasted muscles, resting her body on her knees, her bowed head
hidden as in a cloud by her black wealth of hair.Â  Negore
watched the supple body, bending at the hips as a lynxâs
body might bend, pliant as a young willow stalk, and, withal,
strong as only youth is strong.Â  He looked, and was aware of
a great yearning, akin in sensation to physical hunger.Â  At
last he spoke, saying:
âIs there no greeting for Negore, who has been long gone
and has but now come back?â
She looked up at him with cold eyes.Â  The old man
chuckled to himself after the manner of the old.
âThou art my woman, Oona,â Negore said, his tones
dominant and conveying a hint of menace.
She arose with catlike ease and suddenness to her full height,
her eyes flashing, her nostrils quivering like a
deerâs.
âI was thy woman to be, Negore, but thou art a coward;
the daughter of Old Kinoos mates not with a coward!â
She silenced him with an imperious gesture as he strove to
speak.
âOld Kinoos and I came among you from a strange
land.Â  Thy people took us in by their fires and made us
warm, nor asked whence or why we wandered.Â  It was their
thought that Old Kinoos had lost the sight of his eyes from age;
nor did Old Kinoos say otherwise, nor did I, his daughter.Â 
Old Kinoos is a brave man, but Old Kinoos was never a
boaster.Â  And now, when I tell thee of how his blindness
came to be, thou wilt know, beyond question, that the daughter of
Kinoos cannot mother the children of a coward such as thou art,
Negore.â
Again she silenced the speech that rushed up to his
tongue.
âKnow, Negore, if journey be added unto journey of all
thy journeyings through this land, thou wouldst not come to the
unknown Sitka on the Great Salt Sea.Â  In that place there be
many Russian folk, and their rule is harsh.Â  And from Sitka,
Old Kinoos, who was Young Kinoos in those days, fled away with
me, a babe in his arms, along the islands in the midst of the
sea.Â  My mother dead tells the tale of his wrong; a Russian,
dead with a spear through breast and back, tells the tale of the
vengeance of Kinoos.
âBut wherever we fled, and however far we fled, always
did we find the hated Russian folk.Â  Kinoos was unafraid,
but the sight of them was a hurt to his eyes; so we fled on and
on, through the seas and years, till we came to the Great Fog
Sea, Negore, of which thou hast heard, but which thou hast never
seen.Â  We lived among many peoples, and I grew to be a
woman; but Kinoos, growing old, took to him no other woman, nor
did I take a man.
âAt last we came to Pastolik, which is where the Yukon
drowns itself in the Great Fog Sea.Â  Here we lived long, on
the rim of the sea, among a people by whom the Russians were well
hated.Â  But sometimes they came, these Russians, in great
ships, and made the people of Pastolik show them the way through
the islands uncountable of the many-mouthed Yukon.Â  And
sometimes the men they took to show them the way never came back,
till the people became angry and planned a great plan.
âSo, when there came a ship, Old Kinoos stepped forward
and said he would show the way.Â  He was an old man then, and
his hair was white; but he was unafraid.Â  And he was
cunning, for he took the ship to where the sea sucks in to the
land and the waves beat white on the mountain called
Romanoff.Â  The sea sucked the ship in to where the waves
beat white, and it ground upon the rocks and broke open its
sides.Â  Then came all the people of Pastolik, (for this was
the plan), with their war-spears, and arrows, and some few
guns.Â  But first the Russians put out the eyes of Old Kinoos
that he might never show the way again, and then they fought,
where the waves beat white, with the people of Pastolik.
âNow the head-man of these Russians was Ivan.Â  He
it was, with his two thumbs, who drove out the eyes of
Kinoos.Â  He it was who fought his way through the white
water, with two men left of all his men, and went away along the
rim of the Great Fog Sea into the north.Â  Kinoos was
wise.Â  He could see no more and was helpless as a
child.Â  So he fled away from the sea, up the great, strange
Yukon, even to Nulato, and I fled with him.
âThis was the deed my father did, Kinoos, an old
man.Â  But how did the young man, Negore?â
Once again she silenced him.
âWith my own eyes I saw, at Nulato, before the gates of
the great fort, and but few days gone.Â  I saw the Russian,
Ivan, who thrust out my fatherâs eyes, lay the lash of his
dog-whip upon thee and beat thee like a dog.Â  This I saw,
and knew thee for a coward.Â  But I saw thee not, that night,
when all thy peopleâyea, even the boys not yet
huntersâfell upon the Russians and slew them
all.â
âNot Ivan,â said Negore, quietly.Â 
âEven now is he on our heels, and with him many Russians
fresh up from the sea.â
Oona made no effort to hide her surprise and chagrin that Ivan
was not dead, but went on:
âIn the day I saw thee a coward; in the night, when all
men fought, even the boys not yet hunters, I saw thee not and
knew thee doubly a coward.â
âThou art done?Â  All done?â Negore asked.
She nodded her head and looked at him askance, as though
astonished that he should have aught to say.
âKnow then that Negore is no coward,â he said; and
his speech was very low and quiet.Â  âKnow that when I
was yet a boy I journeyed alone down to the place where the Yukon
drowns itself in the Great Fog Sea.Â  Even to Pastolik I
journeyed, and even beyond, into the north, along the rim of the
sea.Â  This I did when I was a boy, and I was no
coward.Â  Nor was I coward when I journeyed, a young man and
alone, up the Yukon farther than man had ever been, so far that I
came to another folk, with white faces, who live in a great fort
and talk speech other than that the Russians talk.Â  Also
have I killed the great bear of the Tanana country, where no one
of my people hath ever been.Â  And I have fought with the
Nuklukyets, and the Kaltags, and the Sticks in far regions, even
I, and alone.Â  These deeds, whereof no man knows, I speak
for myself.Â  Let my people speak for me of things I have
done which they know.Â  They will not say Negore is a
coward.â
He finished proudly, and proudly waited.
âThese be things which happened before I came into the
land,â she said, âand I know not of them.Â  Only
do I know what I know, and I know I saw thee lashed like a dog in
the day; and in the night, when the great fort flamed red and the
men killed and were killed, I saw thee not.Â  Also, thy
people do call thee Negore, the Coward.Â  It is thy name now,
Negore, the Coward.â
âIt is not a good name,â Old Kinoos chuckled.
âThou dost not understand, Kinoos,â Negore said
gently.Â  âBut I shall make thee understand.Â  Know
that I was away on the hunt of the bear, with Kamo-tah, my
motherâs son.Â  And Kamo-tah fought with a great
bear.Â  We had no meat for three days, and Kamo-tah was not
strong of arm nor swift of foot.Â  And the great bear crushed
him, so, till his bones cracked like dry sticks.Â  Thus I
found him, very sick and groaning upon the ground.Â  And
there was no meat, nor could I kill aught that the sick man might
eat.
âSo I said, âI will go to Nulato and bring thee
food, also strong men to carry thee to camp.âÂ  And
Kamo-tah said, âGo thou to Nulato and get food, but say no
word of what has befallen me.Â  And when I have eaten, and am
grown well and strong, I will kill this bear.Â  Then will I
return in honor to Nulato, and no man may laugh and say Kamo-tah
was undone by a bear.â
âSo I gave heed to my brotherâs words; and when I
was come to Nulato, and the Russian, Ivan, laid the lash of his
dog-whip upon me, I knew I must not fight.Â  For no man knew
of Kamo-tah, sick and groaning and hungry; and did I fight with
Ivan, and die, then would my brother die, too.Â  So it was,
Oona, that thou sawest me beaten like a dog.
âThen I heard the talk of the shamans and chiefs that
the Russians had brought strange sicknesses upon the people, and
killed our men, and stolen our women, and that the land must be
made clean.Â  As I say, I heard the talk, and I knew it for
good talk, and I knew that in the night the Russians were to be
killed.Â  But there was my brother, Kamo-tah, sick and
groaning and with no meat; so I could not stay and fight with the
men and the boys not yet hunters.
âAnd I took with me meat and fish, and the lash-marks of
Ivan, and I found Kamo-tah no longer groaning, but dead.Â 
Then I went back to Nulato, and, behold, there was no
Nulatoâonly ashes where the great fort had stood, and the
bodies of many men.Â  And I saw the Russians come up the
Yukon in boats, fresh from the sea, many Russians; and I saw Ivan
creep forth from where he lay hid and make talk with them.Â 
And the next day I saw Ivan lead them upon the trail of the
tribe.Â  Even now are they upon the trail, and I am here,
Negore, but no coward.â
âThis is a tale I hear,â said Oona, though her
voice was gentler than before.Â  âKamo-tah is dead and
cannot speak for thee, and I know only what I know, and I must
know thee of my own eyes for no coward.â
Negore made an impatient gesture.
âThere be ways and ways,â she added.Â 
âArt thou willing to do no less than what Old Kinoos hath
done?â
He nodded his head, and waited.
âAs thou hast said, they seek for us even now, these
Russians.Â  Show them the way, Negore, even as Old Kinoos
showed them the way, so that they come, unprepared, to where we
wait for them, in a passage up the rocks.Â  Thou knowest the
place, where the wall is broken and high.Â  Then will we
destroy them, even Ivan.Â  When they cling like flies to the
wall, and top is no less near than bottom, our men shall fall
upon them from above and either side, with spears, and arrows,
and guns.Â  And the women and children, from above, shall
loosen the great rocks and hurl them down upon them.Â  It
will be a great day, for the Russians will be killed, the land
will be made clean, and Ivan, even Ivan who thrust out my
fatherâs eyes and laid the lash of his dog-whip upon thee,
will be killed.Â  Like a dog gone mad will he die, his breath
crushed out of him beneath the rocks.Â  And when the fighting
begins, it is for thee, Negore, to crawl secretly away so that
thou be not slain.â
âEven so,â he answered.Â  âNegore will
show them the way.Â  And then?â
âAnd then I shall be thy woman, Negoreâs woman,
the brave manâs woman.Â  And thou shalt hunt meat for
me and Old Kinoos, and I shall cook thy food, and sew thee warm
parkas and strong, and make thee moccasins after the way of my
people, which is a better way than thy peopleâs way.Â 
And as I say, I shall be thy woman, Negore, always thy
woman.Â  And I shall make thy life glad for thee, so that all
thy days will be a song and laughter, and thou wilt know the
woman Oona as unlike all other women, for she has journeyed far,
and lived in strange places, and is wise in the ways of men and
in the ways they may be made glad.Â  And in thine old age
will she still make thee glad, and thy memory of her in the days
of thy strength will be sweet, for thou wilt know always that she
was ease to thee, and peace, and rest, and that beyond all women
to other men has she been woman to thee.â
âEven so,â said Negore, and the hunger for her ate
at his heart, and his arms went out for her as a hungry
manâs arms might go out for food.
âWhen thou hast shown the way, Negore,â she chided
him; but her eyes were soft, and warm, and he knew she looked
upon him as woman had never looked before.
âIt is well,â he said, turning resolutely on his
heel.Â  âI go now to make talk with the chiefs, so that
they may know I am gone to show the Russians the way.â
âOh, Negore, my man! my man!â she said to herself,
as she watched him go, but she said it so softly that even Old
Kinoos did not hear, and his ears were over keen, what of his
blindness.
* * * * *
Three days later, having with craft ill-concealed his
hiding-place, Negore was dragged forth like a rat and brought
before IvanââIvan the Terribleâ he was known by
the men who marched at his back.Â  Negore was armed with a
miserable bone-barbed spear, and he kept his rabbit-skin robe
wrapped closely about him, and though the day was warm he
shivered as with an ague.Â  He shook his head that he did not
understand the speech Ivan put at him, and made that he was very
weary and sick, and wished only to sit down and rest, pointing
the while to his stomach in sign of his sickness, and shivering
fiercely.Â  But Ivan had with him a man from Pastolik who
talked the speech of Negore, and many and vain were the questions
they asked him concerning his tribe, till the man from Pastolik,
who was called Karduk, said:
âIt is the word of Ivan that thou shalt be lashed till
thou diest if thou dost not speak.Â  And know, strange
brother, when I tell thee the word of Ivan is the law, that I am
thy friend and no friend of Ivan.Â  For I come not willingly
from my country by the sea, and I desire greatly to live;
wherefore I obey the will of my masterâas thou wilt obey,
strange brother, if thou art wise, and wouldst live.â
âNay, strange brother,â Negore answered, âI
know not the way my people are gone, for I was sick, and they
fled so fast my legs gave out from under me, and I fell
behind.â
Negore waited while Karduk talked with Ivan.Â  Then Negore
saw the Russianâs face go dark, and he saw the men step to
either side of him, snapping the lashes of their whips.Â 
Whereupon he betrayed a great fright, and cried aloud that he was
a sick man and knew nothing, but would tell what he knew.Â 
And to such purpose did he tell, that Ivan gave the word to his
men to march, and on either side of Negore marched the men with
the whips, that he might not run away.Â  And when he made
that he was weak of his sickness, and stumbled and walked not so
fast as they walked, they laid their lashes upon him till he
screamed with pain and discovered new strength.Â  And when
Karduk told him all would he well with him when they had
overtaken his tribe, he asked, âAnd then may I rest and
move not?â
Continually he asked, âAnd then may I rest and move
not?â
And while he appeared very sick and looked about him with dull
eyes, he noted the fighting strength of Ivanâs men, and
noted with satisfaction that Ivan did not recognize him as the
man he had beaten before the gates of the fort.Â  It was a
strange following his dull eyes saw.Â  There were Slavonian
hunters, fair-skinned and mighty-muscled; short, squat Finns,
with flat noses and round faces; Siberian half-breeds, whose
noses were more like eagle-beaks; and lean, slant-eyed men, who
bore in their veins the Mongol and Tartar blood as well as the
blood of the Slav.Â  Wild adventurers they were, forayers and
destroyers from the far lands beyond the Sea of Bering, who
blasted the new and unknown world with fire and sword and
clutched greedily for its wealth of fur and hide.Â  Negore
looked upon them with satisfaction, and in his mindâs eye
he saw them crushed and lifeless at the passage up the
rocks.Â  And ever he saw, waiting for him at the passage up
the rocks, the face and the form of Oona, and ever he heard her
voice in his ears and felt the soft, warm glow of her eyes.Â 
But never did he forget to shiver, nor to stumble where the
footing was rough, nor to cry aloud at the bite of the
lash.Â  Also, he was afraid of Karduk, for he knew him for no
true man.Â  His was a false eye, and an easy tongueâa
tongue too easy, he judged, for the awkwardness of honest
speech.
All that day they marched.Â  And on the next, when Karduk
asked him at command of Ivan, he said he doubted they would meet
with his tribe till the morrow.Â  But Ivan, who had once been
shown the way by Old Kinoos, and had found that way to lead
through the white water and a deadly fight, believed no more in
anything.Â  So when they came to a passage up the rocks, he
halted his forty men, and through Karduk demanded if the way were
clear.
Negore looked at it shortly and carelessly.Â  It was a
vast slide that broke the straight wall of a cliff, and was
overrun with brush and creeping plants, where a score of tribes
could have lain well hidden.
He shook his head.Â  âNay, there be nothing
there,â he said.Â  âThe way is clear.â
Again Ivan spoke to Karduk, and Karduk said:
âKnow, strange brother, if thy talk be not straight, and
if thy people block the way and fall upon Ivan and his men, that
thou shalt die, and at once.â
âMy talk is straight,â Negore said.Â 
âThe way is clear.â
Still Ivan doubted, and ordered two of his Slavonian hunters
to go up alone.Â  Two other men he ordered to the side of
Negore.Â  They placed their guns against his breast and
waited.Â  All waited.Â  And Negore knew, should one arrow
fly, or one spear be flung, that his death would come upon
him.Â  The two Slavonian hunters toiled upward till they grew
small and smaller, and when they reached the top and waved their
hats that all was well, they were like black specks against the
sky.
The guns were lowered from Negoreâs breast and Ivan gave
the order for his men to go forward.Â  Ivan was silent, lost
in thought.Â  For an hour he marched, as though puzzled, and
then, through Kardukâs mouth, he said to Negore:
âHow didst thou know the way was clear when thou didst
look so briefly upon it?â
Negore thought of the little birds he had seen perched among
the rocks and upon the bushes, and smiled, it was so simple; but
he shrugged his shoulders and made no answer.Â  For he was
thinking, likewise, of another passage up the rocks, to which
they would soon come, and where the little birds would all be
gone.Â  And he was glad that Karduk came from the Great Fog
Sea, where there were no trees or bushes, and where men learned
water-craft instead of land-craft and wood-craft.
Three hours later, when the sun rode overhead, they came to
another passage up the rocks, and Karduk said:
âLook with all thine eyes, strange brother, and see if
the way be clear, for Ivan is not minded this time to wait while
men go up before.â
Negore looked, and he looked with two men by his side, their
guns resting against his breast.Â  He saw that the little
birds were all gone, and once he saw the glint of sunlight on a
rifle-barrel.Â  And he thought of Oona, and of her
words:Â  âAnd when the fighting begins, it is for thee,
Negore, to crawl secretly away so that thou be not
slain.â
He felt the two guns pressing on his breast.Â  This was
not the way she had planned.Â  There would be no crawling
secretly away.Â  He would be the first to die when the
fighting began.Â  But he said, and his voice was steady, and
he still feigned to see with dull eyes and to shiver from his
sickness:
âThe way is clear.â
And they started up, Ivan and his forty men from the far lands
beyond the Sea of Bering.Â  And there was Karduk, the man
from Pastolik, and Negore, with the two guns always upon
him.Â  It was a long climb, and they could not go fast; but
very fast to Negore they seemed to approach the midway point
where top was no less near than bottom.
A gun cracked among the rocks to the right, and Negore heard
the war-yell of all his tribe, and for an instant saw the rocks
and bushes bristle alive with his kinfolk.Â  Then he felt
torn asunder by a burst of flame hot through his being, and as he
fell he knew the sharp pangs of life as it wrenches at the flesh
to be free.
But he gripped his life with a miserâs clutch and would
not let it go.Â  He still breathed the air, which bit his
lungs with a painful sweetness; and dimly he saw and heard, with
passing spells of blindness and deafness, the flashes of sight
and sound again wherein he saw the hunters of Ivan falling to
their deaths, and his own brothers fringing the carnage and
filling the air with the tumult of their cries and weapons, and,
far above, the women and children loosing the great rocks that
leaped like things alive and thundered down.
The sun danced above him in the sky, the huge walls reeled and
swung, and still he heard and saw dimly.Â  And when the great
Ivan fell across his legs, hurled there lifeless and crushed by a
down-rushing rock, he remembered the blind eyes of Old Kinoos and
was glad.
Then the sounds died down, and the rocks no longer thundered
past, and he saw his tribespeople creeping close and closer,
spearing the wounded as they came.Â  And near to him he heard
the scuffle of a mighty Slavonian hunter, loath to die, and, half
uprisen, borne back and down by the thirsty spears.
Then he saw above him the face of Oona, and felt about him the
arms of Oona; and for a moment the sun steadied and stood still,
and the great walls were upright and moved not.
âThou art a brave man, Negore,â he heard her say
in his ear; âthou art my man, Negore.â
And in that moment he lived all the life of gladness of which
she had told him, and the laughter and the song, and as the sun
went out of the sky above him, as in his old age, he knew the
memory of her was sweet.Â  And as even the memories dimmed
and died in the darkness that fell upon him, he knew in her arms
the fulfilment of all the ease and rest she had promised
him.Â  And as black night wrapped around him, his head upon
her breast, he felt a great peace steal about him, and he was
aware of the hush of many twilights and the mystery of
silence.
